metadata.subject: Geography
metadata.description: Earth's rotation, changing duration of day and night, shadow experiments, changing positions of sunrise and sunset

preAssessment.question: The earth completes one rotation around its own axis in _____.
On which two special dates of the year are day and night of equal duration?
When does the longest day of the year occur in the Northern Hemisphere?
The position of sunrise and sunset on the horizon _____ throughout the year.

concepts.title: Earth's Rotation and Day-Night
concepts.content: The earth rotates around its own axis from west to east. It takes 24 hours to complete one rotation ‚Äî this is one day. Because of this rotation, we experience different stages: sunrise, midday, sunset, and night. The side facing the sun experiences day; the side away from the sun experiences night.

examples.text: Sunrise in Mumbai is earlier than in Nagpur because Earth rotates west to east
IST (Indian Standard Time) is based on 82.5¬∞E longitude, one time zone for all of India
When it is daytime in India, it is night in the USA ‚Äî same Earth, different sides

keyPoints: Earth rotates from west to east on its own axis
One complete rotation = 24 hours = 1 day
Rotation causes day and night cycle
Side facing sun = day; side away from sun = night
Different stages in one day: sunrise, midday, sunset, night
concepts.funFact: üåç The Earth's rotation speed at the equator is about 1,670 km/h ‚Äî faster than the fastest jet aircraft! Yet we don't feel it because everything around us moves at the same speed.

concepts.title: Changing Duration of Day and Night
concepts.content: The duration of daytime and nighttime changes throughout the year. In June, days are longer and nights are shorter in the Northern Hemisphere. In December, nights are longer and days are shorter. The textbook activity asks students to note sunrise and sunset times from June to December and record changes in a table.

examples.text: June 21 (Summer Solstice): longest day ~14 hours in North India, shortest night
December 22 (Winter Solstice): shortest day ~10 hours in North India, longest night
March 21 and September 23 (Equinoxes): day and night each exactly 12 hours

keyPoints: Duration of day and night changes throughout the year
In Northern Hemisphere: June has longer days, December has shorter days
Days are longest around June 21 (Summer Solstice)
Days are shortest around December 22 (Winter Solstice)
Activity: record sunrise/sunset times monthly to see the pattern
concepts.funFact: üåû At the North Pole, the sun never sets for 6 months (around April‚ÄìSeptember) ‚Äî it's daylight all day! Then for the next 6 months, there's continuous night. Imagine sleeping in sunshine!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 1: Activity Table ‚Äî Recording Sunrise and Sunset

concepts.title: Shadow Experiment ‚Äî Observing the Sun's Position
concepts.content: The textbook describes a year-long experiment: fix a 1.5‚Äì1.7 m stick vertically near a wall that receives sunlight at sunrise or sunset. Record the position of the shadow once a week. Over the months from June to December, the position of the shadow changes ‚Äî proving that the sun's position on the horizon shifts throughout the year.

examples.text: In June, the sun rises far north on the horizon ‚Äî shadow falls towards south
In December, the sun rises far south on the horizon ‚Äî shadow falls towards north
In September/March, the sun rises exactly in the East ‚Äî shadow falls due west

keyPoints: Fix a long stick vertically; observe its shadow at sunrise or sunset weekly
The shadow's position changes month by month
Changing shadow position = changing position of sunrise/sunset on horizon
This change is caused by Earth's revolution around the sun
Activity must be started in June and continued till December
concepts.funFact: üìê Ancient Egyptians and Indians used shadow-based instruments called 'gnomon' to track the sun's path and determine seasons ‚Äî the same principle as this textbook experiment, used thousands of years ago!

concepts.title: Changing Position of Sunrise and Sunset
concepts.content: As the shadow experiment shows, the position of the rising and setting sun on the horizon is NOT fixed ‚Äî it keeps changing throughout the year. The sun rises exactly in the East only on the two equinoxes (March 21 and September 23). At other times, it rises north of east (in summer) or south of east (in winter) in the Northern Hemisphere. This is connected to Earth's revolution around the sun ‚Äî to be studied further in Chapter 8.

examples.text: June 21: Sun rises towards northeast in Northern Hemisphere ‚Äî longest day
After June 21: sunrise position moves southward day by day
September 23: Sun rises exactly East ‚Äî day = night = 12 hours (Equinox)

keyPoints: Sun does NOT always rise exactly in the East
Equinoxes (Mar 21, Sep 23): sun rises due East, day = night = 12 hours
Summer Solstice (Jun 21): sun rises northeast ‚Äî longest day in Northern Hemisphere
Winter Solstice (Dec 22): sun rises southeast ‚Äî shortest day in Northern Hemisphere
This change happens because Earth's axis is tilted as it revolves around the sun
concepts.funFact: üß≠ Stonehenge in England was built ~5000 years ago specifically aligned to the sunrise position on the Summer Solstice! Ancient peoples were so observant of the changing sunrise position that they built stone monuments to track it.
concepts.textbookRef: Page 2: Observation Activity ‚Äî Sunrise and Sunset Positions

concepts.title: Connection to Seasons ‚Äî A Preview
concepts.content: Chapter 1 is the first part of a two-part lesson on seasons. It establishes through observation that: (1) the duration of day and night changes throughout the year, (2) the position of sunrise/sunset on the horizon changes throughout the year. These observations lead to the question: WHY? The answer ‚Äî the Earth's tilted axis and revolution around the sun ‚Äî is explored fully in Chapter 8 (Part 2), to be studied around December 22.

examples.text: Scientific method: first observe (Ch1), then explain (Ch8)
More direct sunlight = more heat = summer; less direct = less heat = winter
When Northern Hemisphere has summer, Southern Hemisphere has winter ‚Äî opposite seasons!

keyPoints: Chapter 1 is observation; Chapter 8 is explanation ‚Äî they are two parts of the same lesson
Ch1 is taught in June-September; Ch8 is taught around December 22
The changing day length and sunrise position are caused by Earth's tilted axis + revolution
Seasons result from varying intensity and duration of sunlight received
India receives direct sunlight in summer (more heat), oblique in winter (less heat)
concepts.funFact: üåè India experiences a monsoon season ‚Äî a 5th season not seen in most of the world! The monsoon is caused by seasonal reversal of winds, which is itself related to the differential heating of land and sea across seasons.
concepts.textbookRef: Page 2: Note ‚Äî Chapter 8 to be studied around December 22

test.question: How long does the Earth take to complete one rotation on its own axis?
test.explanation: The Earth completes one rotation around its own axis in 24 hours ‚Äî this gives us one complete day (including both daytime and nighttime).

test.question: In which direction does the Earth rotate?
options: Clockwise when viewed from above north pole
test.explanation: The Earth rotates from west to east (anti-clockwise when viewed from the North Pole). This is why the sun appears to rise in the east and set in the west.

test.question: On which dates do day and night have equal duration (12 hours each)?
test.explanation: The equinoxes ‚Äî March 21 (Vernal Equinox) and September 23 (Autumnal Equinox) ‚Äî are the two days when day and night each last exactly 12 hours everywhere on Earth.

test.question: In the shadow experiment, the stick must be fixed _____.
options: Vertically near a wall that receives sunlight at sunrise/sunset throughout the year
test.explanation: The stick must be fixed vertically near a wall that receives sunlight at the time of sunrise or sunset throughout the year so that the shadow position can be observed consistently.

test.question: In the Northern Hemisphere, which month has the longest duration of daylight?
test.explanation: In the Northern Hemisphere, June has the longest days (Summer Solstice around June 21). The opposite is true in the Southern Hemisphere.

test.question: The position of sunrise on the horizon is the same every day of the year.
options: False ‚Äî it keeps changing throughout the year
True ‚Äî it always rises exactly in the East
False ‚Äî it only changes in summer
test.explanation: The position of sunrise on the horizon changes throughout the year. The sun rises due East only on the two equinoxes. At other times it rises north of east (summer) or south of east (winter) in the Northern Hemisphere.

test.question: According to the textbook, when should students start the shadow experiment activity?
test.explanation: The teacher's note says to start the shadow experiment within 8 days after school opens and continue till the end of December, observing once a week at sunrise or sunset.

test.question: Why does the shadow position of the stick change from month to month?
options: Because the sun's apparent position on the horizon changes due to Earth's revolution
Because the stick bends in the wind
Because the Earth rotates faster in some months
Because the sun gets closer to Earth in summer
test.explanation: The changing position of the shadow reflects the changing position of sunrise/sunset on the horizon. This change is caused by Earth's revolution around the sun combined with its tilted axis ‚Äî fully explained in Chapter 8.

test.question: Chapter 1 (Part 1) should be read alongside which chapter that completes the explanation of seasons?
options: Chapter 2: The Sun, Moon and Earth
test.explanation: The textbook note says Chapter 8 (Part 2 of How Seasons Occur) should be handled around December 22. Chapter 1 provides the observations; Chapter 8 provides the scientific explanation.

test.question: If a torch is pointed at a rod on a table and the table is moved sideways, what happens to the shadow?
options: The position of the shadow changes
test.explanation: This experiment illustrates how as the position of the table (representing the Earth) changes, the shadow position changes too ‚Äî just like the Earth's changing position in its orbit causes the sun's apparent position (and shadow) to change.

keyConcepts: Earth's rotation: west to east, 24 hours per rotation
Changing duration of day and night throughout the year
Longest day in Northern Hemisphere: June 21 (Summer Solstice)
Shortest day in Northern Hemisphere: December 22 (Winter Solstice)
Equinoxes (Mar 21, Sep 23): day = night = 12 hours everywhere
Position of sunrise and sunset on the horizon changes daily
Shadow experiment: proves the sun's changing position
Chapter 1 = observations; Chapter 8 = scientific explanation of seasons
commonMisconceptions: The sun always rises exactly in the East ‚Äî FALSE, only on equinoxes
Day and night are always equal in length ‚Äî FALSE, only on equinoxes
Seasons are caused by Earth's distance from the sun ‚Äî FALSE, caused by tilted axis + revolution
Summer is when Earth is closest to the sun ‚Äî FALSE, Earth is actually closest to the sun in January (winter for Northern Hemisphere)
realWorldExamples: Mumbai residents can observe longer evenings in June compared to December
Farmers in Maharashtra use seasonal day-length changes to plan sowing and harvesting
IST (Indian Standard Time) is based on Earth's rotation ‚Äî 1 hour for every 15¬∞ longitude
Solar energy panels in India are tilted at an angle matching India's latitude to maximise sunlight
Uttarayan (Makar Sankranti, Jan 14) ‚Äî celebrated when the sun starts moving northward ‚Äî directly connected to this chapter

formulas.explanation: Earth's rotation period defines one day
On March 21 and September 23 everywhere on Earth
